@irov It sounds like you have more than one copy of the GLFW library in your process. One in each plugin binary, I'm guessing. GLFW does not support this and it would be very difficult to do so.

Try having the plugins share a single GLFW DLL.

this is all the code for fixing this problem

> #ifndef _GLFW_WNDCLASSNAME
> #define _GLFW_WNDCLASSNAME L"GLFW30"
> #endif

how to do pull request?

@elmindreda What if someone happens to use 2 different GLFW applications from different developers? Think those After Effect plugins. One of the developers gets bad review on their app.
There seems to be no proper way for developer to make their app [more or less] unique in that regard.

@irov Your solution will not work, because `_GLFW_WNDCLASSNAME` is used by GLFW during library compilation, so you can't change it when library has been compiled.

However, I'm not sure that it would be **very difficult to do** like @elmindreda said. How I see this could be approached is instead of using `#define`, this string could be kept in a variable. GLFW could provide a Windows-specific API for setting this string, like an initialisation hint or similar.
